section.title: Passives
section.sectiontitle: We can use active constructions when the subject is the person or thing that does the action.
section.text1a: I bought a really fantastic party dress on eBay.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use passive constructions when who or what causes the action is unknown or unimportant.
section.text3: It doesn't matter who found the dog.
section.text3a: The dog was found three days after it went missing.

section.title: Passives
section.sectiontitle: We can use passive constructions when we want to put new information or longer expressions later in the sentence.
section.text1a: The shopping centre was opened by the actress who is in that new film.
section.sectiontitle2: Also use the passive when the object of the active sentence is the main focus. Use by to say who did the action.
section.text3a: A Picasso painting was sold by a wealthy businessman last week.

section.title: Passives
section.sectiontitle: We can use the passive in any tense and with modal verbs. We use a form of the verb to be + past participle.
section.text1a: The papers hadn't been touched for years.
section.text2a: That chair must have been bought by someone with a lot of money.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use passive constructions in writing or in more formal speech. The passive is common in news stories, scientific and academic writing.
section.text3a: Shots were fired and police were called to the scene.
section.text4a: This species is found in coastal areas.
